It was captured on April 9, 1948, during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. The Haganah's operational orders for the area were to 'cleanse' the surrounding villages. items.title: Abu Zurayq
items.content_text: A small village at the foot of Mount Carmel, Abu Zurayq's economy was based on farming grains and vegetables. It was depopulated on April 12, 1948, during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. As part of a counter-offensive, Haganah forces were ordered to capture and destroy the surrounding Palestinian villages. items.title: Balad al-Shaykh
items.content_text: A large and important village at the foot of Mount Carmel, Balad al-Shaykh was the burial site of Izz ad-Din al-Qassam, the revered Syrian cleric and revolutionary leader. items.title: Barrat Qisarya
items.content_text: A small Bedouin settlement near the ancient Roman ruins of Caesarea, Barrat Qisarya's inhabitants were farmers and laborers. The community was depopulated in February 1948. items.title: Butaymat
items.content_text: Butaymat was a small village in the hills southeast of Haifa. items.title: Hawsha

items.title: al-Jalama
items.content_text: Al-Jalama was a village located at a strategic crossroads east of Haifa.
